caption_original:
In August, the Canada C3 Polar Prince secured alongside the CCGS Henry Larsen while at anchor. Both crews had the opportunity to tour each vessel, which was followed by a reception onboard the Henry Larsen.

Photo 1: The vessels are secured together so crews could tour both ships.  

Photo 2: An aerial shot of the Polar Prince and CCGS Henry Larsen secured together. 

Photo 3: Crews of the Polar Prince and the CCGS Henry Larsen pose for a photo with the Canada 150 flag.
caption_cleaned: In August, the Canada C3 Polar Prince secured alongside the CCGS Henry Larsen while at anchor. Both crews had the opportunity to tour each vessel, which was followed by a reception onboard the Henry Larsen. Photo : The vessels are secured together so crews could tour both ships. Photo : An aerial shot of the Polar Prince and CCGS Henry Larsen secured together. Photo : Crews of the Polar Prince and the CCGS Henry Larsen pose for a photo with the Canada flag.

caption_original:
In 1997, a team of hydrographers conducted survey work of Allen Bay, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. They left a time capsule, ashore, beside one of the benchmarks that they used during the survey. It contained a full crew list and a list of the names of the hydrographic team. Byron Briggs, the current Commanding Officer of CCGS Henry Larsen, was part of that 1997 crew list as the Second Officer. The time capsule was later discovered in 2016 by the Bulford family that was hiking in the area. They contacted the Coast Guard shortly after the discovery, to share news of their find. 

In 2017, the Bulfords will complete the last year of deployment in Resolute Bay and wondered if CCGS Henry Larsen was going to be in the area this summer, and if the ship’s crew wanted to see the time capsule before returning it safely to where it was found before winter set in. A crew change in mid-September of 2017 enabled Captain Briggs to return to the ship, in Resolute Bay, in time to welcome all five Bulford family members onboard the icebreaker.  The time capsule was updated with a 2017 ship’s crew list and a list of CHS hydrographers. The Bulfords also included the story of how/when they found it. Who knows when it will be “rediscovered” or by who? 

Photo caption: A photographic keepsake of a great visit aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. Captain Byron Briggs and the Bulford family. In purple, young Lily is seen holding the time capsule she discovered in 2016.

They left a time capsule, ashore, beside one of the benchmarks that they used during the survey. It contained a full crew list and a list of the names of the hydrographic team. Byron Briggs, the current Commanding Officer of CCGS Henry Larsen, was part of that crew list as the Second Officer. The time capsule was later discovered in by the Bulford family that was hiking in the area. They contacted the Coast Guard shortly after the discovery, to share news of their find. In , the Bulfords will complete the last year of deployment in Resolute Bay and wondered if CCGS Henry Larsen was going to be in the area this summer, and if the ship’s crew wanted to see the time capsule before returning it safely to where it was found before winter set in. A crew change in mid-September of enabled Captain Briggs to return to the ship, in Resolute Bay, in time to welcome all five Bulford family members onboard the icebreaker. The time capsule was updated with a ship’s crew list and a list of CHS hydrographers. The Bulfords also included the story of how/when they found it. Who knows when it will be “rediscovered” or by who? Photo caption: A photographic keepsake of a great visit aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. Captain Byron Briggs and the Bulford family. In purple, young Lily is seen holding the time capsule she discovered in .

caption_original: Did you know that the Louis S. St-Laurent, a heavy ice-breaking vessel, is the Canadian Coast Guard’s largest ship at 120 metres long! The ship is currently on the move and is heading to the Arctic for icebreaking operations and scientific programming.
caption_cleaned: Did you know that the Louis S. St-Laurent, a heavy ice-breaking vessel, is the Canadian Coast Guard’s largest ship at metres long! The ship is currently on the move and is heading to the Arctic for icebreaking operations and scientific programming.

caption_original: Happy Labour Day Long Weekend! The Canadian Coast Guard works twenty four seven to ensure safety in Canadian waters. Stay safe!
caption_cleaned: Happy Labour Day Long Weekend! The Canadian Coast Guard works twenty four seven to ensure safety in Canadian waters. Stay safe!

caption_original: Since 2003, the CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent has made an annual mission to the Beaufort Sea to support our Fisheries and Oceans Canada colleagues and their international partners study changing ocean and ice conditions under the Joint Ocean Ice Studies. On last year’s mission we were lucky enough to have writer Peter Lourie join us on board with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) where he documented the importance of this month-long expedition. For a more in-depth look at how we support the science done on this mission and what it’s like to work our largest icebreaker in the Arctic check out his website: https://www.icebreakerstories.com/
caption_cleaned: Since , the CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent has made an annual mission to the Beaufort Sea to support our Fisheries and Oceans Canada colleagues and their international partners study changing ocean and ice conditions under the Joint Ocean Ice Studies. On last year’s mission we were lucky enough to have writer Peter Lourie join us on board with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) where he documented the importance of this month-long eedition. For a more in-depth look at how we support the science done on this mission and what it’s like to work our largest icebreaker in the Arctic check out his website:

Pictured from left are CCGS Constable Carrière, CCGS Samuel Risley, CCGS Limnos and CCGS Cove Isle.

caption_original:
During a rare window of opportunity following a safe escort through ice of the French cruise ship LE BORÉAL by CCGS Des Groseilliers, the cruise ship’s captain invited the icebreaker’s captain and some officers, to board LE BORÉAL, to provide interested passengers and crew with an overview of Arctic icebreaking operations. 

Over 100 very eager passengers attended a brief conference where CCGS Des Groseilliers Captain Michel Dufresne, explained how we break ice, how long the ship can stay in the Arctic and other facets of daily life on board an icebreaker.
caption_cleaned: During a rare window of opportunity following a safe escort through ice of the French cruise ship LE BORÉAL by CCGS Des Groseilliers, the cruise ship’s captain invited the icebreaker’s captain and some officers, to board LE BORÉAL, to provide interested passengers and crew with an overview of Arctic icebreaking operations. Over very eager passengers attended a brief conference where CCGS Des Groseilliers Captain Michel Dufresne, elained how we break ice, how long the ship can stay in the Arctic and other facets of daily life on board an icebreaker.

caption_original:
The CCGS Henry Larsen crew visited Beechey Island, NU, in August, which is the Canadian National Historic Site of the @ParksCanada Franklin Expedition.

Photo 1: CCGS Henry Larsen crew posing with the @Canada150 flag. From left: James McKenna, Gloria Ryan, Mike Dalton, Gerald Strickland, Robert Button, Gerard Chafe, Ron Hardy, Steve McInnis, Paul Park, Darlene McNeil, Jeff Vokey and Howard Wall.

Photo 2: The grave site of the crew from the Franklin Expedition.

Photo 3: Franklin’s Cairn at the top of Beechey Island.

Photo : The grave site of the crew from the Franklin Eedition. Photo : Franklin’s Cairn at the top of Beechey Island.

caption_original: The Arctic Guardian 2017 exercise was executed successfully by the Arctic Coast Guard Forum. This was the first live exercise and an important step towards achieving even closer cooperation between the agencies representing the coast guards in the eight arctic countries - Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Russia, Sweden and USA. We look forward to future exercises! http://ow.ly/7The30f4zPG
caption_cleaned: The Arctic Guardian exercise was executed successfully by the Arctic Coast Guard Forum. This was the first live exercise and an important step towards achieving even closer cooperation between the agencies representing the coast guards in the eight arctic countries - Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Russia, Sweden and USA. We look forward to future exercises!

caption_original:
The Canadian Coast Guard Officer Training Program (CCGOTP) is an exciting opportunity to serve your country while making a real difference on Canada’s waters.

The ultimate goal of the program is to train individuals to become highly motivated and competent Ship’s Officers who will serve at sea in the Canadian Coast
Guard fleet.

http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/College-and-Careers/college

The ultimate goal of the program is to train individuals to become highly motivated and competent Ship’s Officers who will serve at sea in the Canadian Coast Guard fleet.

caption_original:
CCGS George R Pearkes anchored off Port Hope Simpson in support of significant aids to navigation work for the Labrador coast. The CCGS George R Pearkes departed St. John’s, NL to complete a project to improve safety and accessibility to remote aids to navigation sites along the Labrador coast. 

Coast Guard Atlantic Region Marine and Civil Infrastructure technicians undertake concrete pours in Roundhill Island, Fish Island and Snooks Cove, Labrador.
caption_cleaned: CCGS George R Pearkes anchored off Port Hope Simpson in support of significant aids to navigation work for the Labrador coast. The CCGS George R Pearkes departed St. John’s, NL to complete a project to improve safety and accessibility to remote aids to navigation sites along the Labrador coast. Coast Guard Atlantic Region Marine and Civil Infrastructure technicians undertake concrete pours in Roundhill Island, Fish Island and Snooks Cove, Labrador.

caption_original: The CCGS Des Groseilliers provided escorts for a cargo and a cruise ship out of Bellot Strait and through Franklin Strait in Nunavut in late August. These two ships were bound for Cambridge Bay, Nunavut. CCGS DesGroseilliers also escorted an expedition cruise ship in the area.
caption_cleaned: The CCGS Des Groseilliers provided escorts for a cargo and a cruise ship out of Bellot Strait and through Franklin Strait in Nunavut in late August. These two ships were bound for Cambridge Bay, Nunavut. CCGS DesGroseilliers also escorted an eedition cruise ship in the area.

caption_original:
Today marks the official arrival of the fall. Weather is getting colder, outings on the water become increasingly scarce. As such, we want to remind you that our rescue stations in Sorel, Pointe-aux-Anglais and Bainsville will be operational this weekend from Friday, 8 pm, to Sunday, 6 pm. After that, they will cease their activities. This will end the 2017 season of the Inshore Rescue Boat Service in Quebec. For full details, please visit: http://ow.ly/aoLK30fbsHV

Thanks to our teams and see you next year!

As such, we want to remind you that our rescue stations in Sorel, Pointe-aux-Anglais and Bainsville will be operational this weekend from Friday, pm, to Sunday, pm. After that, they will cease their activities. This will end the season of the Inshore Rescue Boat Service in Quebec. For full details, please visit: Thanks to our teams and see you next year!

Polar Bike Project, CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier crew,  and local RCMP, together with the support of Elders and community members helped to bring some smiles to many young faces. This year, even 4 adults were the happy recipients of a bicycle so that they could accompany their children.  We are proud to build relationships with the communities we serve.

caption_original:
Summer is coming to an end, but there are still many days ahead for sailing. Please note that the Canadian Coast Guard’s coastal rescue stations are preparing to phase out their summer activities in Quebec, thus, they will only be in operation until Monday, September 4. After then, services will no longer be offered during weekdays, although, some bases will still be operating during the following three weekends in September: 8-9-10, 15-16-17 and 22-23-24. For full details, see: http://ow.ly/chzK100Msbl 

Please remember, if you go out on Quebec's waterways, make sure to always have the Canadian Coast Guard contact information with you.

caption_original:
The Canada C3 expedition is currently on Leg 12 of their journey. 

They are headed to Prince Rupert.
During this leg the Polar Prince will visit Point Barrow — the northernmost point in the USA, pass the mouth of the Yukon River: the picturesque gateway to the Klondike gold rush and visit the remote Pribilof Islands. 

Follow their journey: http://ow.ly/VF2r30fbkvQ

caption_original:
Have you been following Canada C3's journey? Canada C3 is a signature project for Canada's 150th Anniversary of Confederation. The 150 day sailing journey is connecting Canadians from coast to coast to coast, via the Northwest Passage, with a mission to inspire a deeper understanding of our land, our peoples and the past, present, and future of Canada.

Check out their interactive map to see where they’re headed next: 

https://canadac3.ca/en/expedition/expedition-map/

The day sailing journey is connecting Canadians from coast to coast to coast, via the Northwest Passage, with a mission to inspire a deeper understanding of our land, our peoples and the past, present, and future of Canada. Check out their interactive map to see where they’re headed next:
